data.text: Contents
Initiation of Breast Feeding in a Healthy Term Infant(>2nd Centile Birthweight) ... 5
Introduction

Babies need to feed at frequent intervals and healthy term babies will wake to feed. The term ‘reluctant feeder' refers to newborn babies, who are too sleepy to attach and suck well or who do not wake to feed very often. If a baby has not fed within 2 hours of birth or is not effectively feeding by six to eight hours then it should be considered reluctant to feed.

Reluctant feeding is a common behaviour for many healthy term babies in the first 24-48 hours and mothers will require assistance if they are anxious. Early prolonged skin to skin can encourage babies to feed and increase the likelihood of exclusive breastfeeding (Moore et al 2016).
Most healthy term babies can adapt well to intermittent feeding. Lack of interest in feeding can also be a sign of illness, therefore it is important to monitor these babies closely.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

To ensure that all breastfed babies who are initially reluctant to feed at the breast are correctly managed in a way that maintains adequate health and nutrition and promotes and sustains breastfeeding.
To ensure all staff are aware of the correct management of babies reluctant to breastfed.
This guideline will support this Trust working towards and gaining Baby Friendly Accreditation from UNICEF Baby Friendly Accreditation (BFI).
Definitions
Roles and Responsibilities
The specialist nurse for guidelines and audit is responsible for ensuring
clinical policies, guidelines and SOPs, are evidence-based and developed in  line with national guidelines and following appropriate consultation.
The clinical director is responsible for the implementation of this guidelinewithin  the directorate.
The head of midwifery, maternity matrons and maternity managers are  responsible for ensuring maternity staff are aware of the guideline and  implement it.
The Obstetric Clinical Lead Consultant and Labour Ward Lead Consultant are  responsible for ensuring the implementation of this guideline within the clinical  setting.
All maternity staff are responsible for ensuring they are familiar with this guideline  in relation to their practice and have the appropriate skills to implement this
guideline.
Initiation of Breastfeeding in a Healthy Term Infant (>2nd centile
birthweight)

Following birth, health term newborns will adapt from a constant supply of nutrients via the placenta, to extra-uterine life by the counter-regulatory response. This complex process involves the baby:
Inhibiting the secretion of insulin to help sustain blood glucose levels;
Breaking down glycogen reserves in the liver;
Synthesizing glucose from stores in the liver;
Generating alternative fuels such as ketone bodies to provide protection for the brain and other vital organs.

Therefore healthy term newborns are designed to cope well with initial adjustment and adaption to intermittent feeding. They do not develop hypoglycaemia as a result of simple under feeding. Efforts should be made to keep mother and baby close, to recognise feeding cues and to stimulate a good milk supply.
The following clinical factors exclude babies from this guideline:
Preterm Infants <37 weeks;
Babies of diabetic mothers;
Maternal beta blockers in the third trimester and/or at time of delivery e.g. Labetalol;
Perinatal acidosis (Cord arterial or infant pH <7.1 and base deficit > -12mmol);
Intrauterine Growth Restriction (birth weight on or below the second centile See Appendix 3);
Any clinical reason that could increase the risk of hypoglycaemia.
Babies excluded from this guideline should have follow the Treatment of Neonatal Hypoglycaemia in the High Risk Infant Guideline.
Routine skin to skin and initiation of the first feed
5.5.1 Babies should be dried and placed skin to skin with mothers immediately or as soon
as possible after birth. Ensure that a hat is put on baby, he/she is covered with
warm towels and nursed in a warm environment with ambient temperature of 25̊c. The baby should be placed with their head to the side on the mother's chest
with the face visible. Skin to skin should continue until after the first feed, at least
one hour or until the mother wishes it to end.
5.5.2 Skin to skin contact is the best place for a baby, whilst adjusting to extra-uterine life. Skin to skin helps to regulate heart rate, breathing and temperature. Skin to skin
contact has also been shown to support the initiation of breastfeeding, increase the likelihood of optimal suckling and reduce supplementation with formula whilst in
hospital (Righard & Alade 1990). Most health term babies left undisturbed in skin to skin will feed within the first hour after birth (Widström et al 2011).
If a baby does not feed within an hour
5.6.1 Please follow the flowchart (appendix 1)
5.6.2 Babies may be slow to feed for a number of reasons; these include sedation,

illness, birth trauma and missed opportunity for skin to skin contact (Unicef 2016). After one hour if the baby has not had a breastfeed, reassure the mother that many babies take some time to establish breastfeeding. Discuss with the mother the
value of prolonged skin to skin contact. Close contact with her baby will enhance
the mother's production of oxytocin which will help to ensure good milk production.
5.6.3 Discuss responsive feeding with the mother and make sure she is aware of
newborn feeding cues. Support the mother to hand express her colostrum (See
Appendix 2) Give the baby whatever colostrum you can collect via oral syringe or
cup. Maintain skin to skin, ensuring baby remains warm and close to mum. Review again at no longer than 4 hours after birth.
From 4 hours to  hours after birth
5.7.1 If at 4 hours after birth the baby still has not had a breast feed, complete a full set of observations of the baby.
5.7.2 To include:
Colour;
Tone;
Alertness;
Heart rate;
Respirations;
Temperature;
Consider risk for sepsis.
If there are any concerns or signs of illness, refer to the neonatal team. If there are any risks for hypoglycaemia, follow the MEHT Hypoglycaemia guideline.
Please note ‘Jitteriness, defined as excessive repetitive movements of one or more limbs, which are unprovoked and not in response to a stimulus, is common and is
not by itself an indication to measure blood glucose.' British Association of Perinatal Medicine 2017.
5.8.1  Observations should continue at least 4 hourly until breastfeeding is established.
If the baby appears well but is still disinterested in feeding, support the mother to
hand express her colostrum to give to baby via syringe/cup. Continue to encourage the mother to hand express 2-3 hourly until her baby is breastfeeding. If you are
unable to collect any colostrum continue to support and reassure the mother that
regular stimulation and close contact with her baby will help encourage her milk
supply.
Maintain skin to skin contact for prolonged periods of time. Laid back feeding
position triggers the baby's innate instinct to find the breast and encourage
breastfeeding (Moore et al 2012). Continue to reassure the mother and take steps
to stimulate oxytocin such as dim lighting, warmth, and breast massage. Remember that oxytocin is inhibited by separation of mother and baby, pain, anxiety and
embarrassment.

If the baby shows feeding cues, support her with positioning and attachment if the baby is not able to self-attach. Avoid supplements of artificial formula milk unless clinically indicated. Avoid teats and dummies and ensure that the mother understands the reasons for this.

If the baby is well the plan for skin to skin, frequent hand expression and observations can continue until  hours. If baby continues to be reluctant to feed at 48 hours, refer to the Paediatrician for review. Discuss with the Infant Feeding Team to discuss safe formula supplementation if it is required, whilst supporting lactation.
Do not discharge a baby from hospital care whilst it is still reluctant or unable to breastfeed without having an adequate plan of care in place.
Formula Supplementation

5.14.1 If a mother requests that a formula supplement is given it is important that she is given the information to make an informed choice. Discuss her concerns and preferences. Discuss the risk, benefits and alternatives of the choices available to her. The mother needs to know the following:
Formula supplementation is highly likely to have a negative effect on her milk supply
Giving formula can impair the baby's ability to utilise ketone bodies and counter- regulatory response (De Rooy & Hawdon 2002)
There is a risk of possible allergic sensitisation of the baby to Cow's milk protein allergic.
The benefits of breastfeeding are dose related, with exclusive breastfeeding promoting the best health outcomes for mothers and babies.

Although some babies successfully mixed feed and can transition from breast to bottle and back without issue, it can be associated with causing problems incorrect sucking technique, breast refusal and early cessation of breastfeeding.

The mother should be encouraged to continue to hand massage, express by hand or by pump and have skin to skin contact to stimulate her milk supply and maximise the amount of breastmilk the baby gets. Supplements stickers should be used in the notes to document the care and advice given.
Documentation

Staff must complete documentation of support and discussion as per the  Guideline for Maternity Record Keeping including Documentation in Handheld Records. Baby observations should be documented on a NEWS (Newborn Early Warning Score) chart. The Breastfeeding Assessment tool in the postnatal notes should be completed daily. Supplements stickers should be completed and stuck in the baby postnatal notes to document the care and advice given to evidence informed choice.
Training Requirements
All midwifery and support staff will attend a 2 day Infant Feeding course when first they join the Trust or in case they have not attended the Breastfeeding Update in the last 3 years.
Once staff have attended the full Infant Feeding Course, they are required to attend a mandatory face to face Infant Feeding Update day once every 3 years.
All staff are required to attend a breastfeeding update once a year as part of their mandatory training.

All staff should familiarise themselves with the UNICEF UK Baby Friendly Initiative Standards of maternity services and the role that skin to skin contact plays in successful breastfeeding initiation.
All staff should ensure that their knowledge and skills are up to date in order to effectively support breastfeeding mothers.
Guideline Management

7.6.1 As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.
Monitoring and Audit

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance
Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Patient Safety Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved locally by the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local (Just type over this text guidelines). These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group..

It is the author's responsibility to inform the Maternity and Gynaecology Practice Steering Group and appropriate Maternity Services' staff of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality Impact Assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to appendix 4)
References

Brimdyr K, Widström AM, Cadwell K, Svensson K, TurnerMaffei C (2012) A Realistic Evaluation of Two Training Programs on Implementing Skin-to-Skin as a Standard of Care, Journal of Perinatal Education, Volume 21, Number 3, pp 149- 157(9).

British Association of Perinatal Medicine. (2017) Identification and Management of Neonatal Hypoglycaemia in the Full Term Infant- Framework for Practice. https://www.bapm.org/resources/40-identification-and-management-of-neonatal- hypoglycaemia-in-the-full-term-infant-2017
De Rooy L, Hawdon J. (2002) Nutritional Factors That Affect the Postnatal Metabolic Adaptation of Full-Term Small- and Large-for-Gestational-Age Infants. Pediatrics 109(3):E42
https://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/109/3/e42

Moore ER, Bergman N, Anderson GC, Medley N. Early skin-to-skin contact for mothers and their healthy newborn infants. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2016, Issue 11. Art. No.: CD003519. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD003519.pub4 https://www.cochrane.org/CD003519/PREG_early-skin-skin-contact-mothers-and- their- healthy-newborn-infants
Righard L, Alade MO. Effect of delivery room routines on success of first breast‐ feed. Lancet 1990; 336: 1105– 7.

Widström A-M, Lilja G, Aaltomaa-Michalias P, Dahllöf A, Lintula M, Nissen E (2011) Newborn behaviour to locate the breast when skin-to-skin: a possible method for enabling early self-regulation. Acta Paediatrica. Volume 100, Issue 1, pp 79–85, January.
UNICEF UK Baby Friendly Initiative (2016) Breastfeeding and relationship building workbook. UNICEF, London.

Adapted from British Association of Perinatal Medicine. (2017) Identification and Managament of Neonatal Hypoglycaemia in the Full Term Infant- Framework for Practice.

Appendix 2: Hand Expressing

All mothers who intend to breastfeed should be taught (“hands off” approach) how to hand express their colostrum prior to discharge home. This enables them to ensure their infants receive adequate nutrition in the event they are unable to put their baby successfully to the breast. Hand expression should be attempted prior to any form of formula top up being given and any colostrum expressed given to the baby as a first feeding measure if a baby is reluctant to breastfeed.
How to express your breastmilk
Watching a video on how to do this may help you: http://www.unicef.org.uk/BabyFriendly/Resources/AudioVideo/Hand-expression/  Page  of the Mothers and Others Magazine has useful pictures to follow.
Hand expressing milk simply means squeezing milk out of your breast, and this is how you do it:

☒ A change to an existing policy
☐ A change to the way staff work
What are you proposing to change?

Full review: UNICEF- Baby Friendly Initiative British Association of Perinatal Medicine (BAPM) Identification and Management of Neonatal Hypoglycaemia in the Full Term infant (2017) a change to the exclusion criteria to birthweight on 2nd centile or below. A new flow chart to follow for the management of reluctant to feed babies.
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
To be in line with the hypoglycaemia guideline To support staff with step by step guidance
Who benefits from this change and how?
Staff and patients will benefit from clear guidance in line with national guidelines
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
